transcripts.text: All right.  All righty.  It's time for the mystery yet.  He is the editor-in-chief of this fine magazine, George.  The nation's largest political magazine.  He and the editor of George have a new book out, just came out today, The Book of Political Lists.  Very funny, very interesting.  Please welcome John F. Kennedy,  Jr.,  Well, thanks for coming.  We try to keep it a mystery here.
You did a very good job.

Well, thank you.  Thank you for coming out.  I know you don't usually do these kind of shows, so it's a thrill to have you here.  Now, I know you're a New Yorker.  Jerry's moving to New York.  Any tips?
There's this great soup place.
I don't know.  No, I don't know.  In the 50s.  Really?  How is the service?
He's an ill-tempered guy.  I see.
I'll check it out.  Let me ask you.

I've got to tell you, you've... My judgment in following Mr.  Seinfeld on the biggest night in TV, they always tell you in politics, you've got to watch who you follow.  So I don't know what I was thinking, but it's a great honor to be here on this night.
Yeah.  Now, you weren't on Seinfeld, but you were portrayed, right?
My elbow, I think.  Yeah, you were in the famous contest episode.
Yeah, well, that's right.  I did.  What happened?
I told her about the contest.
Oh, boy, she's a wacko.  Hey, what happened?  What?  I thought you were meeting Kennedy.  I didn't show.  Yeah, you did.
What?  He's out there?
Oh, my God, I got to go.  No, no, no, he just left.
What?  Yeah, he was out there talking to Marla.
Marla?
Yeah, I think, you know, she was, like, crying, and he was consoling her, and then she got into his car, and they just drove away.
He left with Marla the Virgin.  Yeah.  Oh, John.  That was wonderful.

No, it was funny because I hadn't seen the episode and I come out of my house in the morning and everyone is like yelling across the street and I'm walking to work.  You know, I was a district attorney then and people are driving by in their cars and honking.
I'm going, what the hell is going on here?

So I walk in and, you know, people start to say, oh, you know, I saw you last night.  Were you on site?  I said, no, no.  What was everyone talking about?  So they explained it and then I had a trial and I walk I walk into the court, and the defendant is sitting there over there, and he goes, you were on Seinfeld.  And I was like, no, no, I wasn't on Seinfeld.  He leans over to his lawyer, and he goes, the guy's an actor, too.  No wonder he failed the bar exam.
Oh, wow.  Wow.
So, can we go back a second?  Did you say you hadn't seen the episode?  The only one.  It was the only one.  But I got it paid back, so your office is very kind to send it on.
Now, you've been, obviously, around politics your whole life.  Do you think you will ever run?  Would you ever run?  Is that something?  People always...

Well, you know, other than people asking me, were you on Jerry Seinfeld?  So that is the second most frequently asked question.  You know, being an editor of a political magazine, you're able to be in politics without really being in politics.  Right, right.  So it's like... Like being the vice president, I guess.  Yeah.  But it's... I mean, I have a great time doing that, and we all know that politics is a tough profession these days, but I think a very rewarding one.

Well, the magazine is terrific.  I know... I look through it because it gives me great ideas for jokes.  Really?  Well, I like it because it's... I mean, sometimes you read political magazines, it's all sort of... You're very dry, whereas you guys always come at it from a funny angle, which kind of sparks.  And you always do interesting coverage.  You always have people playing.  Who was Dennis Rodman?  What political figure was he?
No, Charles Barkley.  Oh, Barkley.  That's what it was.  Yeah, he was George Washington.
George Washington.

And Harrison Ford was Abraham Lincoln.  Right, right, right.  And Howard Stern was George Washington.  Well, there you go.  which there was a remarkable similarity there.  and uh i mean we've always actually been you know trying for to get you on the cover.  to do you think so yeah who would i?
yeah well actually i think we have we happen to have one is this oh i would i'd love to do it.  who do you?  who would?  i think it's very oh that's lovely lovely.
has anyone seen this?  it's?

uh i see that's And I'm a handsome woman, very busty, apparently.  I'm a very busty woman.  Now we're busting people's pictures.  Let me ask you something, because I know in your life, I always see you, you always seem very dignified and avoid this and avoid that.  And one day I opened George, and there was a picture of you naked.  In your own magazine.  Wait, we have the picture.  There you are right there.
How do you know he's naked?  I can't tell if he's naked.  Yeah, exactly.  He looks like he's wearing shorts.  Exactly.  And running shoes.
No, no.

He could have a very small tuxedo on.  You might not be wearing pants under there.  Exactly.  No one knows that.  Now, were you naked in the photo?  I wasn't, actually.  I was wearing pants and shoes.  You would have perhaps had Newt Gingrich nude from the shoulders down.
I don't think anybody wants to see that.
No, it wasn't.  Everyone always says that no one reads editor's letters, and they read that one.  So what are you going to say?  It worked for the time being, but...
Now, what is the Monica Lewinsky poem that is in here?  Explain this.
Oh, do we have to?  I guess we should.
We should.

We happen to have someone who sent us Monica Lewinsky's poem that she wrote in ninth grade.  Actually, not in ninth grade, when she was a nine-year-old.  And I know I'm going to rot in hell eternally for this, but can I maybe just give it a sample?  Yeah, give a sample.  Okay.  It was written, the poem is a poignant rumination on how, quote, I can be a delicious lunch, dinner, or breakfast, if you're weird.  She goes on to describe herself, quote, as a round and flat piece of dough with lots of topping.  I am a mouth's best friend.  I make you say yum-yum.

It's amazing how kids know at a young age what they're going to do with their lives.  Well, this here is the... Now, this is fascinating, because this is a great sort of reference book, you know, just looking up odd things.  It's a book of celebrity lists.  What is your... No, political list.  I'm sorry, political list.
Political celebrity...
It's almost the same.  What is your favorite?  What is your favorite?

Well, there's a lot of them.  I mean, you know, we try to basically do have a kind of a resource book about politics that also had some funny things in there.  And so that, you know, the whole problem with politics is people often think that it's dull and boring and they don't really appreciate some of the drama or some of the history or some of the funny parts.  So there are.  uh everything from uh code names of presidents to jimmy carter's uh 10 list of 10 favorite desserts that he insisted to.  uh richard nixon's protocol at state dinners.
what was the women?
what was it the women that ran the president?

women who ran for president who couldn't vote for themselves?  there was um you know we there's.  there's obviously lists of men who ran for president who shouldn't be able to vote for themselves.  But the women, one of them, there were two, one of them was named Victoria Woodhull.  She ran for president in 1872.  No one really knows about this, but she was a free love candidate.  And she had two husbands.  And she got 3,000 votes.  And one of her suitors was Cornelius Vanderbilt.  And before she ran for president, she used to get stock tips from him.  And she opened up her own brokerage house in New York and made a killing.  So she was really a woman, a very modern woman way before her time.

Well, that's what's fun.  It makes you realize there's nothing new, really, under the sun.  Everything that's been done has sort of been done.  But it's very funny, just odd facts about various political figures.  Well, listen, it's, of course, the book of political lists and, of course, Georgia Magazine.
Thanks so much for coming.

It's really a pleasure to meet you.  John F. Kennedy, Jr.  July 19th, 1999.  I want to thank you for bearing with us tonight.  I mean, it's kind of hard to do jokes when... you know terrible things happen in the news and I think we've all were affected and I'm trying to understand why so much you know I mean for me growing up in Massachusetts and the Kennedys are so much a part of my life as a kid you know I remember my mom crying when John and Caroline were in the funeral.  you know and it sticks in your mind.  and then when he came here and sat in the chair it struck me that at what point that I think that my life would ever intersect with his life you know and he really made an impression on everybody here genuinely a nice man.  i mean all the kennedy jokes we've done over the years.  he could have been nicer and kinder signed autographs said hello and then my wife and i were talking about it last night.  you know and you realize there there are people.  did you just want to see grow old just just for the fun of it because their life is so close to your life.  you know people like him and princess die and you realize these people never really did any bad.  whenever you saw them you smiled and you felt happy for them and you wanted them to have a good life.  you know.  and for those of you who think somebody has something more than you you go oh boy and then something tragic like this happens.  so Thanks for making the job easier tonight.  Like I said, doing the monologue, I said, how do you go out and do a monologue?  But that's the job we have to do here and try and be silly and try and maybe cheer people up.  But please don't think it's not on our minds because if it's on your minds, it's on our minds too.  So I just want to say, you know, say a prayer and God bless him.  And he was a very, very nice man.  That's all.  Good night, everybody.

All right, my next question, because this is my first season.  So from all your seasons, I know this is hard, because there's probably a lot of them, but what's?  one or two moments that stuck out to you on The Tonight Show, like your favorite moments?

Oh, favorite moment.  You know one moment, and this really stuck out to me, and it's not really a funny moment at all.  I was 13 when John F. Kennedy was assassinated.  And when they had the funeral procession, remember little, everybody here's too young, but little John John was saluting the coffin.  And my mother was just in tears.  You know when you're a kid and your mom's crying, you're like, what can I do here?  And I was sort of helpless and hopeless.  50 years go by.  I have Seinfeld on, my second guest John F. Kennedy Jr.  I saw him come out and then for some reason I started to tear up because I flashed back to my mother crying watching the TV.  And I never thought that triangle would have, I never thought I would know that little boy.  And my mom had passed away by that time, so I could never tell her that he turned out to be okay, you know?  And I didn't flash back to it when I was in the dressing room.  It wasn't until I saw it on the monitor, remember seeing it on TV with my mom, like sitting literally where you are while we're watching the TV in shoes and tears.  And I felt like I wanted to tell her it was okay, you know?  But it was just one of those emotional moments.  And the producer's going, I said, nothing, nothing.  It was just one of those weird things that hit me.  And it only hit me because of that.  I never thought that would ever happen in real life.
Who would have thought?  Yeah, that's a crazy full circle moment.
Not that I brought the show to a screeching halt.
No, no.
You have the coolest stories.
I don't know anyone cool.  Well, it was a fascinating moment.
It was a fascinating moment.
